title: MDX Blog Post
content: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX. tip Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts. <button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button> Click me!

title: Welcome
content: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin. Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory. Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml. The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as: 2019-05-30-welcome.md2019-05-30-welcome/index.md A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images: The blog supports tags as well! And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.

title: Encord SDK
content: Encord SDK üìÑÔ∏è How it Works Encord's Python Software Development Kit (SDK) helps you program mobile applications in one single place. Python SDK enables the user to write codes that manage Oracle Cloud Idenfitier (OCI) resources. The primary purpose of the SDK is to provide an easy-to-use Python environment enabling developers to authenticate a user, retrieve data, and upload data/results. üóÉÔ∏è User Guide 3 items

title: Learn more‚Äã
content: Quickly check how to install Encord's SDK.Learn how to authenticate with Encord.Learn how to use labels.

title: Install Encord's SDK
content: Install Encord's SDK Placeholder to installation guide.

title: User Guides
content: User Guides üìÑÔ∏è Install Encord's SDK Placeholder to installation guide. üìÑÔ∏è Authenticate Authentication is the process you use to confirm your identity through credentials, thus proving that you are who you say you are. üìÑÔ∏è Use Labels Labeling is used to identify raw data, such as images, videos, etc, and provide context so that a machine learning model learns from it. For example, labels may be used to indicate if a video contains cars, or if an ultrasound shows a tumor.

title: Set up public key authentication‚Äã
content: A public-private key pair is required for authentication. Register the public key with Encord and use your private key as your credentials.

title: Requirements‚Äã
content: Linux/MacOS: use the default terminalWindows 10 & Server 2019/2022: use Powershell

title: Generate a public-private key pair‚Äã
content: Take the following steps to set up public key authentication (for SSH): Open a terminal. Run the following command: ssh-keygen -t ed25519 Type the file location where both private and public keys will be stored, as follows: For Mac users: > Enter file in which to save the key (/Users/YOU/.ssh/id_ALGORITHM): /Users/YOU/.ssh/id_encord For Windows users: > Enter file in which to save the key (C:\Users\YOU/.ssh/id_ALGORITHM): C:\Users\YOU/.ssh/id_encord For Linux users: > Enter file in which to save the key (/home/YOU/.ssh/id_ALGORITHM): /home/YOU/.ssh/id_encord In the following prompts, press enter (do NOT type any passphrase): > Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase): [Press ENTER] > Enter same passphrase again: [Press ENTER] The following files are generated: /path/to/your/key/id_encord contains your private key (which you should handle carefully)./path/to/your/key/id_encord.pub contains your public key (usually in a file ending in .pub).

title: Add the public key to Encord‚Äã
content: Now that you set up your public-private key pair, you must add the public key to Encord's webapp. In the terminal, run the following command: $ cat /path/to/your/key/id_encord.pub Select and copy the content of id_encord.pub file displayed in the terminal.In Encord's UI, open the User icon and select Settings. Select Public keys and + New key.Choose a name for your public key and paste the previously copied content. tip The key should have the following format: ssh-ed25519 <several characters>. Select Create to register your key. You are now ready to authenticate with your private key.

title: Authenticate with private key‚Äã
content: info Note that, in this step, you should have already installed Encord's SDK. If you haven't taken this step yet, learn how to install Encord's SDK. To authenticate with Encord, add the following snippet to your Python script: from pathlib import Path from encord.user_client import EncordUserClient # adapt the following line to your private key path private_key_path = Path.home() / ".ssh" / "id_encord" with private_key_path.open() as f: private_key = f.read() user_client = EncordUserClient.create_with_ssh_private_key(private_key)

title: Prepare your data for labeling‚Äã
content: Placeholder for how to prepare data for labeling.

title: Read labels‚Äã
content: To successfully read labels, take the following steps: Authenticate using your private key. If you haven't set up your private key yet, follow the instructions in the Authenticate page. Access annotations by adding the Project class, as follows: from encord.project import Project def get_project(self, project_hash: str) -> Project: """ Get the Project class to access project fields and manipulate a project. You will only have access to this project if you are one of the following * Project admin * Project team manager * Organisation admin of the project Args: project_hash: The Project ID """ config = SshConfig(self.user_config, resource_type=TYPE_PROJECT, resource_id=project_hash) querier = Querier(config) client = EncordClientProject(querier=querier, config=config) return Project(client) Get all the label details by adding the EncordClientProject.get_label_row class, as follows: from typing import Iterable, List, Optional, Set, Tuple, Union from encord.orm.label_row import ( AnnotationTaskStatus, LabelRow, LabelRowMetadata, LabelStatus, Review, ShadowDataState, ) def get_label_row( self, uid: str, get_signed_url: bool = True, *, include_object_feature_hashes: Optional[Set[str]] = None, include_classification_feature_hashes: Optional[Set[str]] = None, include_reviews: bool = False, ) -> LabelRow: """ Retrieve label row. If you need to retrieved multiple label rows, prefer using :meth:`encord.project.Project.get_label_rows` instead. A code example using the `include_object_feature_hashes` and `include_classification_feature_hashes` filters can be found in :meth:`encord.project.Project.get_label_row`. Args: uid: A label_hash (uid) string. get_signed_url: Whether to generate signed urls to the data asset. Generating these should be disabled if the signed urls are not used to speed up the request. include_object_feature_hashes: If None all the objects will be included. Otherwise, only objects labels will be included of which the feature_hash has been added. include_classification_feature_hashes: If None all the classifications will be included. Otherwise, only classification labels will be included of which the feature_hash has been added. include_reviews: Whether to request read only information about the reviews of the label row. Returns: LabelRow: A label row instance. Raises: AuthenticationError: If the project API key is invalid. AuthorisationError: If access to the specified resource is restricted. ResourceNotFoundError: If no label exists by the specified label_hash (uid). UnknownError: If an error occurs while retrieving the label. OperationNotAllowed: If the read operation is not allowed by the API key. """ return self._client.get_label_row( uid, get_signed_url, include_object_feature_hashes=include_object_feature_hashes, include_classification_feature_hashes=include_classification_feature_hashes, include_reviews=include_reviews, )
